newsitem.title: DUBAI: Iran centrists plan to form political party.
newsitem.headline: Iran centrists plan to form political party.

text.p: An influential group of Iranian centrists and technocrats who helped elect moderate cleric Mohammad Khatami as Iran's next president said they would soon form a political party.
The Servants of Construction, also known as the Group of Six (G6), said they hoped there would be no legal impediment to Interior Ministry approval, Iranian newspapers said on Sunday.
"A formal announcement of the political party will be made after two months," Iran News daily quoted a source close to the centrists as saying.
The reason was that they expected it would be easier to form a political party after Khatami's inauguration in August as President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani's successor, newspapers said.
The group, formed ahead of March 1996 parliamentary elections, includes Vice-President Mohammed Hashemi, Central Bank Governor Mohsen Nourbaksh and Tehran mayor Gholamhussein Karbaschi.
Iranian newspapers said four more prominent politicians had joined including Faezeh Hashemi, Rafsanjani's daughter who was elected to parliament for the first time last year.
Political parties were banned in Iran after the 1979 Islamic revolution. Groups or factions, such as G6, form to support individual politicians.

Others include the Association of Militant Clergy, a group of conservative Shi'ite Moslem clerics including parliament speaker Ali Akbar Nateq-Nouri, who was heavily defeated in the May 23 presidential election.
